# Review PLURAL Missingness
# Env Exposures & Segregation 1940 to 2010
# Elizabeth Blake

Description: In this file, Elizabeth has reviewed all counties missing PLURAL (rurality) data, looked at RUCA measures, Census records, and other maps, and input suggestions on the rurality of counties missing the rurality measure. These counties are missing the value becuase PLURAL is based on Census places, and if a specific county does not have a Census place, then the county level PLURAL value would be missing.

```{r load packages}
if(!requireNamespace("pacman", quietly = TRUE)) install.packages("pacman")
pacman::p_load(here, folders, readr, dplyr, tidyr, stringr, purrr, knitr, snakecase, ggplot2, ggmap, sf, tigris, MetBrewer, tidyverse, sp, readr, ggnewscale)
```

```{r load data}
# Be sure to edit this filepath to match your computer's filepath
counties_missing_plural <- read_csv("data/merged_data/counties_missing_plural.csv")

counties_missing_plural <- counties_missing_plural %>%
  mutate(plural_notes = if_else(str_detect(plural_notes, "no place in county"), NA, plural_notes))

# sum(is.na(counties_missing_plural$plural_notes))

# RUCA: https://www.ers.usda.gov/data-products/rural-urban-commuting-area-codes/ 
# Census Records: https://catalog.archives.gov/search-within/821491; https://www.census.gov/library/publications/1942/dec/population-vol-1.html
```

RUCA, or Rural-Urban Commuting Areas, are being used as a comparison because they are a commonly used metric to measure rurality in the 2000s. These values would help us gain more detailed information about the rurality or urbanicity of a county in 2010.

The links above to Census Records are helpful because they provide some access to older maps, including from the 1940s, which may be useful in understanding the rurality of a county at that time period. They also provide population counts for 1940 for a variety of spatial units.
